mainText.attr1: Because part of the fun of games is discovering how they work - I'm not going to cover this topic in as much detail as it entails.
The attempt is made for ships to react intelligently/logically to enemies.
Ship will tend to seek out fights.
The attempt is made for ships to be independent.
Ships have combat roles - which are defined by what ships/objects they will prioritize when the choice exists.
Example: fighter drone will attack fighter drones, then fighters, then corvettes.
Example: A bomber will prioritize corvette ships and higher before attacking a fighter.
Example: a cruiser will ignore fighter drones all together (though its defensive turrets might not)
The attempt is made for ships be obedient when given orders.

If you noticed a conflict between independence and obedience then congratulations, contradictions like these are a big challenge of game design - especially when it comes to a hybrid game. AI is a wide topic, and good AI varies based on games and goals.

In Void Destroyer my concept of good AI is that it seeks out fights - combat being the main focus of the game. So ship AI is given independence to do so - this independence can allow for the player playing the pilot role - and knowing that friendly forces will engage enemies - on their own.
However - also - being a RTS - friendly units need to obey player orders. Otherwise giving orders would be a waste of time (not to mention frustrating).

Luckily we can somewhat easily prioritize player commands and not allow (in most cases) for ships to ignore player commands. In addition there are a few tools to be aware off (see the Controlling Ship Behaviour topic).
